Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: INFEWS N/P/H2O: Electrochemical Approaches to Sustainable Dinitrogen Fixation
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, scientists from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), Yale University, and Rutgers University are collaborating to develop approaches to sustainable electrochemical fixation of nitrogen (N2). Sustainable nitrogen fixation is central to the nexus of challenges in food, energy, and water chemistry. Current global food production is enabled by the use of synthetic fertilizer that is produced by nitrogen fixation processes that generate ammonia (NH3) from nitrogen and hydrogen (H2), but leave a dramatic negative impact on energy and the environment, consuming about 2% of the world?s fossil fuel-derived energy supply. In this project, Prof. Alexander Miller (UNC), Profs. James Mayer and Patrick Holland (Yale), and Profs. Alan Goldman and Gal Hochman (Rutgers) are exploring new, sustainable methods for nitrogen fixation. New chemistry will be developed that could enable the development of electrochemical nitrogen fixation processes that do not require consumption of fossil fuels to produce ammonia and nitrates. Sustainability and policy analysis will assess the potential for transformative impact on global agriculture and energy sectors (including consideration of ammonia as a possible liquid transportation fuel). The project will train graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in interdisciplinary problem-based scientific methods and positively impact institutional infrastructure. The topic and the results of the research will be used as a platform to teach non-scientists about the importance of chemical catalysis in industry, agriculture, and modern society in general.

The interdisciplinary research team has strengths in catalyst design and synthesis, electrocatalysis, mechanistic studies, and sustainability and policy analysis. The chemical approach to N2 fixation involves transition-metal-electrocatalyzed reductive splitting of N2 into nitrido intermediates. These nitrido intermediates can undergo (a) nitride reduction to NH3 by proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET), or (b) nitride oxidation toward nitric acid. Middle-to-late transition metal complexes of robust and tunable pincer ligands will be an experimental focus, with complementary computational studies to correlate reactivity with molecular properties and guide catalyst development. The cost of potential electrochemical N2 fixation processes will be analyzed, to estimate the dependence on a range of factors such as diversity of electricity sources, intermittency of sustainable energy, and governmental policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research project established new insights into the fundamental chemistry underpinning the development of catalysts for the electrochemical fixation of nitrogen (N2), in parallel with forward-looking studies of the economic feasibility of possible electrochemical processes.  

The chemical research focused on a particular pathway for N2 fixation, via its splitting into nitrido intermediates (M≡N). These intermediates could then either be (a) directed to ammonia (NH3) by proton-coupled electron transfer, or (b) be oxidized toward nitric acid. A variety of molybdenum, rhenium, and ruthenium complexes supported by robust tridentate “pincer” ligands were prepared and subjected to careful mechanistic studies of individual steps along the proposed N2 fixation pathways. These collaborative studies provided the first example of electrochemically driven N2 splitting into terminal metal nitride complexes, the key step in pathway (a). This discovery enabled electroanalytical mechanistic studies that elucidated the nature of early steps in the N2 binding and activation process. The first example of rhenium-mediated N2 reduction all the way to NH3 was also demonstrated, a process that relied on photochemical N2 splitting followed by proton-coupled electron transfer reduction of the resulting nitride complex. The proton-coupled electron transfer reactions were followed up with quantitative studies on N-H bond strengths. These studies provide foundational design principles for converting N2 to NH3 in solution. 

Finding a way to directly proceed from a nitrido intermediate to oxidized nitrogen compounds and nitric acid (path b) is attractive because it could be far more efficient than the current process. Explorations of this novel approach afforded new insight into the reactivity trends of mid-transition metal nitride complexes, and isolation of reactive rhenium(VI) complexes. These studies also revealed many of the challenges that need to be overcome to find a route from N2 to nitric acid without oxidizing other groups on the catalyst.

Economic studies focused on identifying conditions under which a future electrochemical ammonia synthesis process could be competitive with existing technology. A key finding was that an integrated electrochemical N2 fixation process was always more cost effective than a tandem water electrolysis / Haber-Bosch process. Even without considering the social costs of carbon emissions associated with the Haber-Bosch process, the electrochemical nitrogen reduction process was attractive under conditions where the cost of electricity varied substantially, as is often the case when renewable energy sources are utilized. 

This work has broad impact because nitrogen fixation chemistry directly impacts the entire food, energy, and water nexus. Ammonia, currently produced by the hydrogenation of N2 via the Haber-Bosch (H-B) process, is the source of virtually all of the world's synthetic fertilizers, and supports half of all global food production. Fertilizer synthesis, however, has a dramatic negative impact the environment, consuming about 2% of the world’s fossil fuel-derived energy supply and releasing commensurate amounts of CO2. These studies build the fundamental knowledge that will lead to electrochemical alternatives that use sustainable energy together with water and N2 to form ammonia fertilizer. Through this research, 8 graduate students, 2 postdoctoral scholars, and 7 undergraduate students were trained in interdisciplinary scientific methods. Students and PIs involved the larger community through outreach events that taught diverse junior high and high-school students the role of chemical catalysis at the intersection of food, energy, and water challenges.
